awd_titl_txt: A Professional Learning Community for Advancing Community College Education and Student Success (ACCESS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California Berkeley Museum of Paleontology (UCMP) will lead a one-year virtual conference to establish a Professional Learning Community (PLC) of community college instructors and graduate students to support the development of teaching resources for diverse audiences. The PLC builds upon existing partnerships with community colleges and resources developed as part of the ACCESS (Advancing Community College Education and Student Success) program to make the geosciences and practices of scientific inquiry more accessible to all learners. While Earth science literacy and perspectives from diverse stakeholders are essential for addressing 21st century societal and environmental challenges, the geosciences remain one of the least diverse STEM disciplines. By partnering with community colleges, the program will serve students who identify as low-income, first-generation, or underrepresented minorities. The ACCESS program is uniquely positioned to help enhance online and in-person geoscience learning experiences for students while simultaneously helping community college instructors and UC Berkeley graduate students develop inclusive pedagogical practices to enhance their teaching skills. 

The ACCESS PLC will support the revision and implementation of inquiry-based lessons for diverse audiences using active, equitable, and inclusive learning practices known as Model-Based Inquiry. Through a year-long series of workshops and meetings, the PLC will develop lessons that deepen students’ understanding of the Earth history and processes, which is necessary to contextualize the complexity and urgency of global climate and local environmental challenges. Efforts to enhance STEM education that focus on issues related to diversity and inclusive practices are typically one-time efforts and not a continual means of providing professional development and support for instructors. Year-long support for instructors and iterative development of resources in the UCMP ACCESS PLC will help transform and sustain shifts in teaching practices as we face the ongoing challenges of providing online and blended learning experiences for students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to establish a Professional Learning Community (PLC) of community college instructors and graduate students to support the development of geoscience teaching resources for diverse audiences. We accomplished this by facilitating a series of workshops and meetings providing support for instructors to help transform and sustain shifts in teaching practices for students in Earth and related sciences. In doing so, the workshop built upon existing partnerships with community colleges and resources developed as part of the University of California Museum of Paleontology (UCMP) ACCESS (Advancing Community College Education and Student Success) program to make the geosciences and practices of scientific inquiry more accessible to all learners. The outcomes produced are new and enhanced online and in-person modules and geoscience learning experiences for students at the participating community colleges students and support for community college instructors and UC Berkeley graduate students develop active, equitable, and inclusive learning materials  informed by Model-Based Inquiry (MBI) and Ambitious Science Teaching (AST) practices.

Over the three year period, we engaged eight community college instructors and five graduate students in a workshop series that introduced them as learners to MBI and AST practices, especially how to interweave data-driven learning with iterative, explanatory conceptual modeling activities. We supported instructors and graduate students to identify geoscience phenomena that could motivate and sustain student learning, and to use active learning and inquiry-based instructional practices in the materials they designed. The instructors and the graduate students became better equipped to develop or refine ACCESS resources and also integrate these practices throughout their teaching. Teachers were excited to engage students in collaborative work and learning sequences that more accurately reflect the nature and process of science in which students gather evidence to construct conceptual models that explain their understanding of a focal geoscience phenomenon. These phenomena include the dynamics of urban heat islands, hurricane damage, or the end-Cretaceous mass extinction, and organismal biogeography. The Community College instructors have shared that the lab practices help students build many important skills from confidence in working with data to designing solutions, communicating ideas, and revising initial hypotheses.  Students have increased agency in their own work, and practice skills that require more critical thinking and better represent a realistic scientific process. These modules were implemented in a range of introductory courses that explore Earth systems, Earth materials, Earth history, and oceanography. The PLC team has disseminated the learning materials and shared outcomes and assessment tools  in sessions at national meetings about introductory geoscience courses.
